info.document:
CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Looking at the real world, we live on a smallish and almost round rock with a molten core formed a few billion years ago. It has certainly changed lots since its fiery start as oceans formed, continents appeared and later drifted, meteors struck and ice ages dawned and receded.

Also, consider the fact that our home planet is carrying us at over 1 million miles per hour through our universe. (And you thought you move pretty fast at 70 mph on the freeway.)

Our planet, with us along for the ride, rotates once around in what we define as a day. For our particular spot that translates to a bit over 800 miles per hour. Earth circles the Sun from about 90 million miles away, traveling during a year more than 550 million at over 60,000 mph. Also, keep in mind the axis of the Earth is tilted as it rotates daily at about 23 degrees creating our seasons.

Starting to get the picture?

Now, our solar system circles the center of our Milky Way Galaxy in what is defined as a galactic year, estimated to be about 250 million of our Earth years. The speed is around 500,000 mph.

Been a while since I researched this one, but several local galaxies along with our Milky Way are traveling towards a common destination within our universe. This gang is called the Local Group and travels in excess of another 600,000 mph and held together by gravity, if you can imagine that. Dark matter may play a role.

The result is that we are traveling in a giant corkscrew fashion in excess of 1 million miles per hour. Wow, is all of this enough to have some impact on the planet's climate?

A clear and current man-made impact on our climate is called UHI, or Urban Heat Island effect. The mayor of Los Angeles, in a lengthy Feb. 12 article in the L.A. Times, estimated the heat generated by the city's asphalt, concrete and building structures at 3 degrees Fahrenheit. He declared the need to plant trees to help.

Trees have a great way of providing shade while their leaves evaporate water in a process called transpiration. Transpiration provides cooling as the water taken in by the roots travels, nurtures the tree and evaporates from the surface of the leaves.

Trees are a natural air conditioner, as is our rain. L.A. will need many thousands of trees, but it is a great first step.

Man-made changes due to deforestation, urbanization and suburbanization, removal of grasslands and wetlands all add into the human made forms of climate change.

At least in our Coachella Valley all the golf courses provide some real cooling. When I walk in the summer in the very early morning, I can feel the cooling effect along the edges of my local golf course with its grass and trees. They can even use recycled water if available

Take a look around and imagine the UHI impact present everywhere. You will understand that we all have an impact on climate change.

Our city, county and state planners need to take the UHI effect seriously and leave room for urban forests, grass lands, lakes, ponds and parks. And, as L.A. Mayor Eric Garcetti plans to do, plant many more trees.

Email Barry Morgan of Rancho Mirage at bsmorgan1@yahoo.com.
